units.title: hPSC thawing and passaging
units.text: The hPSCs are routinely maintained in feeder-free conditions in commercially available mTeSR Plus medium (STEMCELL Technologies). Routine testing for mycoplasma is performed, and hPSCs are discarded if they test positive. Extracellular matrix Matrigel and various Matrigel alternatives have been used to coat the plates for the expansion of hPSCs. In this manuscript, although we still use the term ‘Matrigel’ to indicate the extracellular matrix, we actually use a Matrigel alternative, Cultrex (R&D Systems), in our laboratory rather than the traditional Matrigel (BD Biosciences). No differences between the two extracellular matrixes are observed in supporting hPSC expansion. The hPSCs are passaged by using a gentle dissociation method using Versene solution (or 0.5 mM EDTA solution) to get small clumps for replating. If hPSCs are thawed for experimental use, it is highly recommended to let them recover for two to three passages before proceeding for differentiation. We recommend using hPSC lines with no more than 75 passages.
units.rationale: This excerpt details the standardized procedure for maintaining and passaging hPSCs prior to differentiation, including critical reagents and handling steps.

units.title: hPSC-to-iNPC differentiation protocol
units.text: Day 0. Before initiating the differentiation, first aspirate the culture medium and wash with 1 ml of PBS, before adding 1 ml of the phase I medium (Table 6). ... Days 2 and 3. Replace with 1.2 ml of fresh phase 1 medium. ... On day 4, aspirate the phase I medium and add 1.2 ml of phase II medium (Table 6). ... Days 5 and 6. Renew the medium with 1.2 ml of fresh phase II medium. ... On day 7, aspirate the phase II medium and add 1.2 ml of phase III medium (Table 6). ... Days 8 and 9. Renew the medium with 1.2 ml of fresh phase III medium.
units.rationale: This sequence describes the precise, stage-specific medium changes during the 10-day hPSC-to-iNPC differentiation protocol with critical timing and reagent instructions.

units.title: iNPC purification by FACS using dual reporter
units.text: FACS of iNPCs through BD FACSAria III cell sorter. For the SIX2-GFP;PAX2-mCherry dual reporter hPSC line, GFP+;mCherry+ iNPCs are sorted as shown in Fig. 2c. See also Supplementary Fig. 1a for an example of full FACS gating plots.
units.rationale: This step specifies the exact FACS sorting criteria and equipment used to isolate iNPCs based on reporter expression, a key procedural detail.

units.title: iNPC expansion in hNPSR-v2 medium
units.text: Once the hPSC-derived iNPCs have been purified via FACS, they are immediately cultured in hNPSR-v2 medium. Within 2–3 d, these iNPCs form clusters in culture as observed for the culture of primary human NPCs. hNPSR-v2 medium is refreshed every 1–2 d. Once the iNPCs reach a confluency of 80–90%, they are dissociated into single cells with Accumax and passaged at a 1:10 split ratio on Matrigel (Cultrex)-coated plates.
units.rationale: This describes the core culture protocol for expanding iNPCs, including medium refreshment, confluency thresholds, dissociation reagent, and passaging ratio.

units.title: iNPC cryopreservation
units.text: 200,000–1,000,000 cells can be frozen in 0.5 ml of Bambanker cell freezing medium per cryovial (1.5-ml Nalgene SYSTEM 100 cryogenic vial). To do so, after Step 39, first count the total number of cells harvested. Then, calculate the number of cryovials needed on the basis of the total number of cells. Centrifuge the cells at 300g for 5 min, resuspend the cell pellet with an appropriate volume of Bambanker cell freezing medium and distribute a 0.5-ml aliquot of the cell suspension in each cryovial.
units.rationale: This provides the exact cell count range, freezing medium volume, and procedural steps for reliable long-term iNPC storage.

units.title: nephron organoid formation from iNPCs
units.text: The expandable iNPCs can be used for nephron organoid formation. Once the iNPCs have reached a confluency of 80–90%, they are dissociated into single cells and reaggregated at 30,000 cells per aggregate to form iNPC aggregates overnight in 96-well U-bottom low-attachment plates. iNPC aggregates are then gently transferred to a six-well Transwell plate for air–liquid interface culture. The aggregates are treated with 6 µM CHIR99021 for 1 h (phase I medium), which mimics the natural epithelization signal in vivo. For the first 5 d, the aggregates are cultured in phase II medium containing FGF9. Starting from day 5, culture medium is switched to phase III medium, which supports the maturation of nephron cell types until day 21.
units.rationale: This outlines the complete, actionable protocol for generating nephron organoids from iNPCs, including cell density, aggregation, Transwell transfer, and staged medium changes.

units.title: nephron organoid characterization by immunostaining
units.text: To prepare samples for immunostaining, remove the Transwell insert from the six-well plate and peel the whole Transwell membrane off by using fine forceps (organoids should stay on the top of the membrane). Use a blade or fine scissors to cut the Transwell membrane into smaller pieces (~5 mm), with each piece containing one organoid in the center. Use forceps to transfer each Transwell membrane piece with an organoid into one 1.5-ml Eppendorf tube containing 200 µl of 10% (vol/vol) FBS medium. Aspirate the 10% (vol/vol) FBS medium and add 200 µl of 4% PFA (wt/vol) for fixation at room temperature for 12 min. Aspirate the 4% PFA and wash the organoid with 500 µl of PBS three times. Aspirate the PBS after the last wash. Add 500 µl of blocking buffer and incubate for 30 min at room temperature. Aspirate the blocking buffer and add 200 µl of blocking buffer containing the desired primary antibodies for incubation overnight at 4 °C. Aspirate the primary antibody solution and add 500 µl of PBST to wash the well three times. Aspirate the PBST after the last wash and add 200 µl of blocking buffer containing the desired secondary antibodies for incubation overnight at 4 °C. Aspirate the secondary antibody solution and then wash the well with 500 µl of PBST three to five times. Use forceps to hold the Transwell membrane piece and transfer the piece with an organoid onto a microscope slide. Remove excessive PBST and then add ~20 µl of mounting medium. Carefully place a microscope coverslip on the sample (avoid bubble formation). Seal the sample with clear nail polish surrounding the coverslip.
units.rationale: This is a detailed, step-by-step protocol for preparing and staining nephron organoids for immunofluorescence, including critical handling and incubation steps.

units.title: iNPC quality control by immunostaining
units.text: For that, after dissociating the cells (Step 39), count the cell density and seed 100,000 cells into one 1.7-ml Eppendorf tube and then centrifuge at 300g for 5 min. Resuspend the pellet with 100 µl of hNPSR-v2 medium and seed into one well of a Matrigel-coated 96-well plate. On the next day, these cells will attach to the plate and are ready for immunofluorescence staining directly in the 96-well plate. Aspirate the culture medium and add 50 µl of 4% PFA (wt/vol) aqueous solution to fix the cells for 10 min at room temperature. Aspirate the 4% PFA fixative from the well and wash the well with 100 µl of PBS three times. Aspirate the PBS after the last wash and add 100 µl of blocking buffer for 20 min. Aspirate the blocking buffer, add 60 µl of blocking buffer containing the desired primary antibodies and incubate for 1 h at room temperature. Aspirate the primary antibody solution and add 100 µl of PBST to wash the well three times. Aspirate the PBST after the last wash, add 60 µl of blocking buffer containing the desired secondary antibodies and incubate for 30 mins at room temperature. Aspirate the secondary antibody solution and then wash the well with 100 µl of PBST three times.
units.rationale: This provides the standardized immunostaining protocol for routine iNPC quality control, specifying cell seeding, fixation, antibody incubation, and washing steps.

units.title: preparation of hNPSR-v2 medium
units.text: Once the individual component stocks are properly prepared as outlined above, thaw the aliquots of component stocks and use them to prepare 100 ml of complete hNPSR-v2 medium by referring to Table 4. All stock aliquots can be used for the preparation of 100 ml of complete hNPSR-v2 medium, except for 10 mM A83-01 stock (first stock), which needs to be further diluted by mixing 1µl of 10 mM A83-01 with 199 μl of DMEM/F12 medium to make a 50 μM A83-01 stock solution (second stock). The thawed stock medium components have different shelf-lives. For growth factors, it is best to store them at 4 °C and use them within 2 weeks. For small molecules, including the second stock of A83-01, they are good for ≤1 month at 4 °C. The complete hNPSR-v2 medium can be stored at 4 °C for 2 weeks.
units.rationale: This details the precise formulation and handling instructions for preparing and storing the critical hNPSR-v2 medium used for iNPC expansion.

units.title: preparation of phase I, II, and III media for nephron organoid differentiation
units.text: Phase I medium: Advanced RPMI 1640 medium – – 9.791 ml; GlutaMAX-I (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; Pen-strep (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; CHIR99021 10 mM 8 μM 8 μl; LDN193189 10 μM (second stock) 10 nM 1 μl. Phase II medium: Advanced RPMI 1640 medium – – 9.788 ml; GlutaMAX-I (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; Pen-strep (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; Y-27632 10 mM 10 μM 10 μl; Activin A 50 μg ml−1 10 ng ml−1 2 μl. Phase III medium: Advanced RPMI 1640 medium – – 9.795 ml; GlutaMAX-I (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; Pen-strep (100×) 100× 1× 100 μl; FGF9 100 μg ml−1 50 ng ml−1 5 μl.
units.rationale: This provides the exact volumetric composition of the three critical differentiation media for nephron organoid generation, including concentrations and volumes of all components.
